title-group.article-title: Finite element implementation of Puck’s failure theory for fibre-reinforced composites under three-dimensional stress

contrib-group.aff: Institute for Statics and Dynamics of Aerospace Structures (ISD), University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany

author-notes.corresp: H Matthias Deuschle, Institute for Statics and Dynamics of Aerospace Structures (ISD), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 27, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany Email: Matthias.Deuschle@gmx.de

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The objectives of this article are to apply Puck’s failure criteria to predict the failure of 12 test problems, proposed in Part A of the second World-Wide Failure Exercise. These problems include a polymer material, various unidirectional laminae and three multi-directional laminates under a variety of 3D stress loadings. The implementation was carried out through a commercial finite element code where material nonlinearities, due to material behaviour under shear and transverse and through-thickness loadings and due to post failure damage, were taken into account. This is the first time where the critertion has been stretched to its limits. Some of the challenges found include the need to determine the fracture angle of action plane under 3D stresses and the treatment of the strengthening effects on the nonlinear stress strain curves when a lamina is subjected to combined compressive stresses in both the transverse and through-thickness directions. The successful methodology developed here will be used to analyse the effects of boundary conditions in Part B of the second World-Wide Failure Exercise to improve correlation with experimental results for the test problems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Engineering composite materials have been present in research and industry for several decades. It is only recently, however, that composites have truly started to replace conventional materials in primary structural assemblies in aircraft industry. The Airbus A380’s wing box, the most important part of the structure since it transfers the load between the wings and the fuselage, is completely made of fibre-reinforced composite (FRC) materials.1 This great advance has been made possible by the massive increase of computing power in the last two decades. Along with being able to use more complex models, the components that can be studied to predict the failure behaviour can also be a lot more detailed. Based on the growing reliability of in-plane failure prediction,2 the application of FRC has been extended to complex geometries including primary load transferring components, resulting occasionally in three-dimensional (3D) loading of the material. A safe design of such materials and structures requires an efficient and reliable failure prediction under general 3D states of stress.

Puck’s action-plane related failure criteria for unidirectional (UD) fibre-reinforced polymer composites3 are 3D formulations ab initio, which have already proven their capability in the first World-Wide Failure Exercise4,5 under 2D stresses. Combined with adequate degradation procedures, they are a promising tool for the prediction of lamina failures and the postfailure load redistribution in laminates. The quality of any stress (strain)-related failure prediction is strongly influenced by the preceding stress (strain) analysis. Aiming on geometries far beyond a plane layer composition, analytical tools making use of the classical laminate theory (CLT) are obviously falling short of a finite element analysis (FEA). In particular, commercial FEA packages like ABAQUS6 provide verified user-friendly algorithms for all kinds of nonlinear constitutive behaviour, the simulation of the curing process and the prediction of interface failure (delamination). Thus, the present work focuses on the implementation of Puck’s failure criteria for lamina failure to join the established tools.

A second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II) was launched by Kaddour and Hinton7 to assess the capability and maturity of current 3D failure criteria. In the exercise, the originators of composite failure theories were invited to take part by agreeing to provide two papers (Part A and Part B) describing their model and its correlation with test data. The organisers provided a set of 12 Test Cases to challenge the current failure criteria and a set of guidelines to help the participants. The authors, after a personal consultation with Puck, have accepted to participate as the exercise was seen to provide an opportunity to illustrate the usefulness of Puck’s theory and to validate its applicability to problems involving 3D stresses. The present article represents the authors’ first contribution (Part A) to WWFE-II and is divided into three parts. The first part introduces Puck’s failure criteria for fibre/polymer composites in terms of general 3D formulations (see ‘Puck’s theory’ section). Then, its implementation into FEA and the calculation of material behaviour by means of representative volume elements (RVEs) is discussed (see ‘Failure and post-failure behaviour prediction using FEA’ section) before the results of 12 Test Cases7 are presented in detail (see ‘Results of the WWFE-II Test Cases’ section).

sec.title: Puck’s theory
sec.p: Puck’s criteria for fibre fracture (FF) and interfibre fracture (IFF) of unidirectionally reinforced (UD) composites are physically based on hypotheses and mathematical formulations appropriate for brittle fracture.3,8–10 They have been adapted by Puck to the transversely isotropic UD fibre/polymer composites.

Of main importance for IFF are the stressing σ⊥ transverse to the fibres and the two different shear stressings – in-plane shear stressing τ⊥‖ and through-thickness shear stressing τ⊥⊥. The term stress prevalently implies stresses in the rectangular global or lamina coordinate system. Being a transversely isotropic material however, a UD lamina is stressed by σ2 and σ3 in the same way. Hence, the term stressing is used to emphasise that values in the cylindrical coordinate system of a UD lamina (σ⊥,σ‖,τ⊥‖,τ⊥⊥) are addressed. Conventional failure criteria are formulated with basic strengths R⊥ t, R⊥ c, R⊥‖ and R⊥⊥ belonging to the basic stressings. Every single strength is measured by the application of its particular stressing homogeneously to a UD-volume element up to failure. In a failure criterion without physical basis, it is irrelevant where and how failure occurs because the measured uniaxial strengths act as anchor points for an analytical curve without physical meaning only.

While the general approach is the same when using action plane-related fracture criteria following Mohr and Puck, the kind and location of a fracture do matter. In this case, the combined stresses acting on a common action-plane have to be related to the strengths of that action-plane. These strengths are the amount of a single stressing σ⊥ t or τ⊥‖ or τ⊥⊥ that an action plane can bear. Demanding an accurate distinction between these figures and usual strengths, Puck has introduced the term fracture resistance of the action plane RA for the necessary action plane-related material description and has formulated the following definition:

A fracture resistance of the action plane is the resistance (expressed in the dimension of a stress) by which an action plane resists its own fracture due to a stress in the considered action plane caused by one of the basic stressings σ⊥ or τ⊥⊥ or τ⊥‖.
The adequate question when determining a fracture resistance of an action plane is then:

To which amount can a single stressing (σ⊥ t/c or τ⊥⊥ or τ⊥‖, see Figure 1) be increased before a fracture occurs in exactly that action plane to which the respective stressing is applied? Figure 1.
Basic stressings of a unidirectional-lamina and their action planes (grey).

To determine the common strength of a material, it is sufficient to divide the maximum bearable load by the cross section area. To interpret experimental results in terms of action plane-related fracture criteria, it is important to know whether the fracture has occurred in the action plane of the applied stressing or not. Figure 2 shows that not for all the basic stressings this is the case. In almost all UD laminae, a tensile stressing σ⊥ t leads to a fracture plane perpendicular to the applied stressing. In this case, the fracture plane and the action plane of the applied stressing coincide, thus the strength of the material R⊥ t and the fracture resistance of the action-plane R⊥ At have the same value. The same is the case when measuring R⊥‖ A. An applied single τ⊥‖-stressing leads to a shear fracture on its action plane and thus R⊥‖ A has the same value as R⊥‖. It should be noted that a corresponding τ‖⊥ will also be acting. However, the fracture resistance of its action plane R‖⊥ A is much higher than R⊥‖ A due to the fibre reinforcement and thus the consideration of τ‖⊥ is irrelevant. Figure 2.
Fracture planes of an intrinsically brittle unidirectional-composite under uniaxial or pure shear stressing (from Knops3).

In contrast to the two cases above, a single compressive stressing σ⊥ c cannot separate the material in its action-plane, which is perpendicular to σ⊥ c (see Figure 2 and cp. Figure 1). The UD-element fractures due to the resulting shear stressing τ⊥⊥ on an oblique fracture plane. Furthermore, it is impossible to produce a fracture in the action plane of an applied τ⊥⊥, the UD-element fractures due to a tensile stressing σ⊥ t on an oblique fracture plane.

A central conclusion from Puck’s considerations is that there are no more than three stresses acting on a common action plane (σ⊥, τ⊥‖ and τ⊥⊥) and thus exactly three fracture resistances of the action plane RA are needed. Two of them (R⊥ At and R⊥‖ A) can be derived directly from the usual strengths of the material but R⊥⊥ A needs further consideration (see ‘Puck’s action plane-related IFF-criteria’ section) including the following experimental observation: A superposed tensile σ⊥ t on an action-plane lowers the bearable shear while a superimposed compressive σ⊥ c on an action-plane increases its intrinsic fracture resistance against τ⊥‖ and/or τ⊥⊥.

To clearly distinguish between applied states of stress and the resulting stresses on an action plane, it is essential to be familiar with the stress components acting on a plane. The most general stress combination on any section plane (and a fracture plane in particular) of an isotropic material consists of one normal stress σ and one shear stress τ. The same situation exists in a UD composite on a section plane, which is parallel to the fibres. However, in a UD lamina, the shear vector is examined by means of its two components τnt and τn1. The first index n means that both are acting on the same action plane, which is perpendicular to the direction xn. The second index indicates the direction of the shear stress τ. Its component τnt is acting transversally and τn1 parallel to the fibre direction x1 (Figure 3). Figure 3.
Definition of shear stresses in an section plane, from Puck.15

From a micromechanical aspect, these two components of τnΨ in either fibre-parallel or fibre-transverse direction are certainly behaving a little different in terms of shear fracture. This fact is represented by two different fracture resistances of the action plane against shear (R⊥⊥ A and R⊥‖ A) and therefore, when dealing with strengths, τnt and τn1 are treated separately. But if only the combined force of τnt and τn1 is of interest, it is reasonable to look at their resultant shear stress (1)τnΨ=τnt 2+τn1 2

Schematically then – like in isotropic material – on a common stress action plane exist only one normal stress σn and one shear stress τnΨ. Note that the corresponding τΨn acts in a plane intersecting the fibres (Figure 3) – the fracture resistances of such planes are much higher than of fibre-parallel action planes hence they do not play a role in the fracture analysis.

sec.title: Application of Puck’s IFF criterion
sec.p:
For the 2D stress analysis, simplified analytical equations were formulated to show the various IFF criteria, see Table 1 in Puck and Schürmann.4 Three distict modes of failure were formulated, and these are referred to as Mode A, Mode B and Mode C, as shown in Figure 4. Mode A is predicted under combined transverse tension and shear of a lamina. Mode B dominates the lamina behaviour under combined shear and moderate transverse compression. Mode C is predicted to dominate failure undere large compression loading, combined with a shear load. Figure 4.
Visualisation of the stretch factor fS in the fracture curve of plane states of stress. Table 1.
Recommended inclination parameters
p⊥‖ t p⊥‖ c p⊥⊥ t, p⊥⊥ c
GFRP 0.30 0.25 0.20–0.25
CFRP 0.35 0.30 0.25–0.30
GFRP: glass fiber reinforced polymer; CFRP: carbon fiber reinforced polymer.

Fo the general 3D state of stress, numerical search for the fracture plane is needed. There is an infinite number of action planes, which are all potential fracture planes. Hence, the action plane with the highest risk of fracture has to be identified before fracture stresses can be calculated.

For this purpose, the stretch factor fS is calculated for a large number of sections (normally 180) between θ=[-90∘;90∘]. The term fS is the factor, by which the stress vector σ→=[σn(θ),τnt(θ),τn1(θ)] on the considered action plane must be proportionally increased (stretched) to cause the fracture of that specific plane (Figure 4). In other words, fS is sort of a reserve factor between the stresses acting on a specific action plane and the fracture limit of the respective plane (equation (2)).

On action planes without stress or only compressive σn acting, fS would take the numerically objectionable value ∞ (see Figure 5, at θ=-45∘, i). Thus the reciprocal value of fS, called the stress exposure fE, is more appropriate for both analysis and graphical representation (equation (2)). While the term stretch factor is intentionally similar to a reserve factor, the stress exposure, which increases linearly with the applied stress is a direct measure for the risk of fracture (2)fE=1fS=length>of>the>actual>stress>vectorσ→length>of>the>vectorσ→frof>the>stressesleading>to>fracture Figure 5.
Stress exposure fE(θ) for an applied τ23, partly from Puck.15

The analysis results in the identification of that plane at θfp, which needs the lowest stretch factor fSmin to fracture. Obviously, this plane will exclusively reach its fracture limit if the applied external stress is increased by the factor fSmin while the rest of the planes with fS>fSmin will stay below (Figure 5(ii)).11

sec.title: Puck’s action plane-related IFF-criteria
sec.p: The action plane-related stresses are derived from the applied stresses as follows (3)σn(θ)=σ2·cos2θ+σ3·sin2θ+2τ23·sinθ·cosθτnt(θ)=-σ2·sinθ·cosθ+σ3·sinθ·cosθ+τ23 ·(cos2θ-sin2θ)τn1(θ)=τ31·sinθ+τ21·cosθ
Corresponding to these three stresses that cause a σ⊥-, a τ⊥⊥- or a τ⊥‖-stressing, respectively, three fracture resistances of the action plane must be known: R⊥ At, R⊥⊥ A and R⊥‖ A.

If, for instance, a single stressing σ⊥ t is applied to a brittle material, it leads to a fracture plane parallel to its action plane. Following Paul,10 this behaviour is called intrinsically brittle. Intrinsically brittle behaviour is defined as follows: If there are any sections on which the applied stresses lead to tension σn t, the fracture occurs in the section with the largest normal tension σn t. According to that in case of a pure σ⊥ t-stressing, the applied stress at the time of fracture is the corresponding strength and also the corresponding fracture resistance of the action plane. Assuming that the present composites behave intrinsically brittle, the following identity of strength and action plane fracture resistance is valid (4)R⊥ At=R⊥ t

If a pure τ⊥‖-stressing is applied to a UD composite, the embedded fibres force the fracture to occur in a fibre-parallel section. Thereby, the action plane of the τ⊥‖-stressing will experience the highest τ⊥‖-stressing compared to any other action plane inclined by an angle θ. Thus, for transverse/longitudinal shear, there is always valid (5)R⊥‖ A=R⊥‖

In contrast to that, R⊥⊥ A is extremely different from the transverse shear strength R⊥⊥. Up to now, R⊥⊥ A is not accessible experimentally because the fracture of intrinsically brittle materials due to an applied τ⊥⊥ -stressing does neither occur in its action plane nor is it a shear fracture: A single τ23-stress leads to tensile fracture in an action plane, which is inclined by 45° to the action plane of the applied τ23 (Figure 5). For the time being, R⊥⊥ A is determined from a uniaxial transverse compression test where the applied σ⊥ c leads to a τ⊥⊥-shear fracture in a fracture plane at about θfp≈±54∘. While, in the action plane at θ=45∘, there obviously acts the highest τnt, there also acts a fracture-obstructing compressive σn c of the same magnitude. This declines towards the actual fracture plane at ±54∘ where the shear fracture due to τnt occurs. The fact that shear fracture due to τnt only occurs with superimposed σn c requires the reconstruction of R⊥⊥ A using the calibrating inclination parameter p⊥⊥ c (equation (6)). The meaning and definition of p⊥⊥ c is discussed later (see ‘Mathematical description of the MFB’ section) (6)R⊥⊥ A=R⊥ c2(1+p⊥⊥ c)

sec.title: Visualisation of the IFF criterion
sec.p:
The IFF conditions can easily be visualised in the 3D stress space of the action plane (σn,τnt,τn1) – they describe the master fracture body (MFB). All the stress vectors that stay inside the MFB can be sustained without fracture; in other words, the MFB envelopes all sustainable (σn,τnt,τn1)-combinations. Due to the different effect of a tensile or compressive σn on the development of IFF, the MFB-surface consists of two parts joining at a common cross section at σn=0. The known anchor points are R⊥ At on the σn-axis, ±R⊥⊥ A on the τnt-axis and ±R⊥‖ A on the τn1-axis (Figure 6). Figure 6.
The master fracture body (MFB) in the action plane-related (σn,τnt,τn1)-stress space, from Knops.3

As τnt and τn1 both cause a shear stressing acting on a common fibre parallel action plane (cp. Figure 3), the corresponding fracture resistances of the action plane R⊥⊥ A and R⊥‖ A should not differ a lot. Thus, it seams reasonable to assume a simple elliptical fracture criterion for combined (τnt,τn1)-states of stress τnΨ at σn=0 (Figure 6(b)) (7)(τnΨR⊥Ψ A)2=(τntR⊥⊥ A)2+(τn1R⊥‖ A)2=1forσn=0

Having fixed the cross section at σn=0, Puck decided to describe the MFB by longitudinal sections rather than further cross sections. The reason is that the tip of a stress vector, which is proportionally stretched by the stretch factor fS (cp. ‘Application of Puck’s IFF criterion’ section), is moving in a longitudinal section of the MFB. This fact leads to a rather simple equation for a longitudinal section.

Those parts of the MFB surface where an applied plane (σ2,τ21)-stress combination leads to a fracture in its own action plane (θfp=0∘) can easily be investigated experimentally. This is the case in the whole positive range of σ2>0 and a small part of the negative σ2≈[-0.4R⊥ c;0]. Within these two ranges, there is θfp=0∘ and accordingly σ2=σn, τ21=τn1 and τnt=0. That means that all the resulting IFF fractures are placed on a longitudinal contour line of the MFB in the (τnt=0)-plane.

For positive σn, the (σn,τn1)-fracture curve can be described well by a branch of an ellipse, which cuts the σn-axis perpendicularly at σn=R⊥ At and the positive τn1-axis at τn1=R⊥‖ A with a declining slope of about δτn1/δσn=-0.3 (Figure 6(a)). According to Coulomb,8 the fracture curve continues in the negative σn-region as an inclined straight line. To ensure conservative results however, a diminishing dependence of the fracture resistances of the action plane against shear from negative σn is assumed. Thus, Puck chose a parabolic contour line in this region (p. 54ff).3 This assumption follows Mohr’s idea that the strengthening effect of compressive σn decreases with growing compressive σn.

Finally, the whole MFB arises from the set of ellipse/parabola-contour lines for all angles Ψ. For positive σn, the result is a calotte with the utmost point on the σn-axis at σn=R⊥ At and τnΨ=0. Looking in negative σn-direction, the MFB looks like an infinite, slightly widening funnel. This meets the fact that σn alone never causes fracture. There is always a specific amount of τnΨ necessary for fracture, and this amount grows with increasing compressive σn.

sec.title: Mathematical description of the MFB
sec.p: In the following, a contour line of the MFB is described by an ellipse in the σn≥0 half space and by a parabola in the σn<0 half space (8)(τnΨR⊥Ψ A)2+c1σnR⊥ At+c2(σnR⊥ At)2=1 forσn≥0 (9)(τnΨR⊥Ψ A)2+cσn=1 forσn<0
The ellipse has to include three anchor points (Figure 6(c)), which are (10)[σnτnΨ]=[R⊥ At0]on>theσn-axis and [0±R⊥Ψ A]on>theτn>Ψ-axis
With equation (1) and the geometric relations τnt=τnΨcosΨ and τn1=τnΨsinΨ, it follows from equation (7) (11)R⊥Ψ A=[(cosΨR⊥⊥ A)2+(sinΨR⊥‖ A)2]-12

While the ellipse crosses the σn-axis perpendicularly, it should cross the τnΨ-axis with an inclination, which can be chosen within specific limits (equation (12)). Recommended values will be presented later in this section (12)(δτnΨδσn)σn=0 ellipse= {-p⊥Ψ tforτnΨ>0p⊥Ψ tforτnΨ<0

The parabola describing the contour line of the MFB in areas σn<0 starts at the anchor points (σn=0,τnΨ=±R⊥Ψ A ) and its inclination may differ slightly from the inclination of the ellipse joining at that point (13)(δτnΨδσn)σn=0 parabola= {-p⊥Ψ cforτnΨ>0p⊥Ψ cforτnΨ<0
With the above conditions, the constants c1, c2 and c (cp. equations (8) and (9)) become (14)c1=2p⊥Ψ tR⊥ AtR⊥Ψ A (15)c2=1-2p⊥Ψ tR⊥ AtR⊥Ψ A (16)c=2p⊥Ψ cR⊥Ψ A

For the inclination values at Ψ=90∘, that means the longitudinal section of the MFB where only σn and τn1 exist (τnt=0), there is some experimental experience concerning the inclination parameters p⊥Ψ t and p⊥Ψ c, which are named p⊥‖ t and p⊥‖ c in that particular case. The present analysis follows the recommendations given in VDI-Gesellschaft Kunststofftechnik12 and Puck et al.13 also for the values p⊥⊥ t and p⊥⊥ c valid in the longitudinal section of the MFB at Ψ=0∘ (Table 1).

Having chosen the inclinations of the contour lines at Ψ=0∘ and 90°, Puck uses the following interpolation procedure (equation (17)) to define the values of p⊥Ψ t and p⊥Ψ c at any angle Ψ. The procedure ensures a harmonic behaviour of the change in inclination around the circumference of the MFB (17)p⊥Ψ t,cR⊥Ψ A=p⊥⊥ t,cR⊥⊥ Acos2Ψ+p⊥‖ t,cR⊥‖ Asin2Ψ with (18)cos2Ψ=τnt 2τnt 2+τn1 2 and (19)sin2Ψ=τn1 2τnt 2+τn1 2

With equation (7), the MFB is completely described by equations (8) and (9), which are polynomials of second order of the stresses. The right hand side of the equations set to the value 1 makes them a fracture condition. This means, σn and τnΨ calculated using these equations are stresses at IFF. If stresses lower than these are inserted in the left hand side of the equations (8) and (9), the result is a figure lower than 1. Though this indicates that these stresses are bearable without IFF, the figure itself does not represent the stress exposure (cp. ‘Application of Puck’s IFF criterion’ section). It was stated that the stress exposure fE should increase linearly with proportionally increasing stresses – this is not the case in the quadratic equations (8) and (9). Thus, they have to be rearranged to form a homogeneous function in the first degree of the stresses. This can be easily achieved by dividing the stress terms of the first order by fE and those of the second order by fE 2. Then, the general solution of the resulting quadratic equation for fE can be written as (20)fE=12(∑L+(∑L)2+4∑Q) where ∑L is the sum of the stress terms of first order, ∑Q the sum of those of second order. Applying this term to the fracture conditions (equations (8) and (9)) leads to the two central expressions of Puck’s IFF criterion (21)fE=12(∑L+(∑L)2+4∑Q) for σn≥0 and (22)fEIFF(θ)=(τnt(θ)R⊥⊥ A︸Eq.6)2+(τn1(θ)R⊥‖ A)2+(p⊥Ψ cR⊥Ψ A︸Eq.23σn(θ))2 +p⊥Ψ cR⊥Ψ A︸Eq.23σn(θ) for σn<0 where (23)p⊥Ψ t,cR⊥Ψ A=p⊥⊥ t,cR⊥⊥ A︸Eq.6cos2Ψ︸Eq.18+p⊥‖ t,cR⊥‖ Asin2Ψ︸Eq.19
Setting fE=1 and θ=θfp, equations (21) and (22) are a different form of the fracture conditions equations (8) and (9).
Using these two equations (equations (21) and (22)), the orientation θfp of the expected fracture plane can be identified (24)⌊fEIFF(θ)⌋max=fEIFF(θfp)

sec.title: Considerations on different IFF fracture modes
sec.p: In the design of critical components, it is of extraordinary importance to know which stresses and strengths of the material are of primary relevance for a failure. Regarding IFF, Puck’s action plane-related fracture criteria now offer the relevant information by identifying the orientation of the fracture plane and the stresses acting on it.

The most astonishing conclusion from the considerations above is that: All the presented fracture modes are described exclusively by equations (21) and (22). This is possible due to a two-stage analysis: First, the criteria are used to identify the orientation of the fracture plane θfp, and in a second step, they are used to calculate the fracture stresses on that very plane.

Although in the 3D case, the categorisation into Modes A, B and C seems no longer adequate, the differentiation between fractures with positive or negative σn on their fracture plane is still significant regarding the consequences of the fracture: While fractures with σn t acting on their fracture plane are generally supposed to be tolerable if the load can be redistributed to neighbouring laminae, fracture planes with σn c indicate the risk of an abrupt fatal desintegration (local splitting and delamination) of the laminate by their wedge effect5,15 if a compressive σ2 is present.

sec.title: Influences on the IFF beyond Mohr’s hypothesis
sec.p: In the context of this section it is important to stress that Puck’s IFF criteria predict brittle macroscopic IFF failure by means of cracks through the entire thickness of the lamina. Although the theory leaves the preceding microdamage-induced nonlinearities to the stress analysis (see ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section), it does account for the influence of microdamage on the IFF.

It was previously stated that only stresses (σn,τn1,τnt) acting on the fracture plane are relevant for the fracture itself (cp. ‘Puck’s theory’ section). In accordance with Mohr,9 neither the fibre parallel stress σ1 nor the levels of IFF stress exposures on planes other than the fracture plane have been included so far. Considering the gradual development of an IFF due to the progressive formation of microcracks and for probabilistic reasons, there are states of stress where a pure Mohr approach is expected to be on the nonconservative side. Therefore, the following two extensions of the IFF criteria have been developed by Puck beyond Mohr’s hypothesis.

sec.title: Influences of fibre-parallel stress σ1 on the IFF
sec.p: According to Mohr, the stress σ1 does not have any influence on an IFF because that stress’ action plane is perpendicular to any possible IFF fracture plane – thus σn(θ), τn1(θ) and τnt(θ) are independent from σ1 (equation (3)). Experiments, however, have revealed a series of effects, which require the inclusion of a σ1-term to reduce the IFF strength somewhat.15 The most essential effect is explained by the statistical scatter in the fibre strength. Macroscopically detected FF at |σ1|=R‖ is the moment, when a very large number of elementary fibres breaks and the UD lamina loses most of its load-bearing capacity in fibre direction. Statistical laws state that some elementary fibres will already have been broken before the FF limit R‖ of the UD lamina has been reached16 – this is the case for both FFs (tensile σ1) and fibre kinking (compressive σ1). The result of those micro-FFs is a local damage of the UD lamina in the form of a local fibre-matrix debonding and microfractures in the highly loaded neighbouring matrix material.17 They weaken the overall fibre-matrix cohesion and, thus, reduce its resistance against IFF. This problem has been addressed recently by Correa et al.,18 where Boundary Element methods were employed in conjuction with Interfacial Fracture Mechanics concepts. They examine the effect of the interfibre/matrix failure under biaxial transverse loadings using micromechanical formulations.

In order to include the weakening effect of σ1 in the IFF analysis, the fracture resistances of the action planes are reduced by a weakening factor ηw1=[0;1]. This factor can be used in the tensile and compressive range of σ1 in the same way. For the sake of simplicity, ηw1 has the same value for all the three fracture resistances R⊥ At, R⊥⊥ A and R⊥‖ A. This assumption has the effect that the orientation of the fracture plane θfp is independent from ηw1 since σ1 is independent from θ.3 That means the identification of the fracture plane will be carried out the same way whether including the σ1-influence or not.

Regarding the definition of ηw1, the considerations of Puck and Schürmann5,15 may be explained by studying the fracture curve of a simple (σ2,σ1)-load case (Figure 7) in the first quadrant. Gradually starting at a specific σ1-value (horizontal tangent, see Figure 7(i)), the weakening effect increases with increasing σ1 but presumably leaves some IFF fracture resistance when reaching the FF limit (ii). Hence, the weakening is described by a fracture curve in the form of a segment of an ellipse. The segment starts at s·R‖(s=[0;1]) and ends at the FF-limit |σ1|=R‖. Here, the bearable σ2 reaches its minimum m·R⊥ t(m=[0;1]). Both m and s can be chosen freely between their limits and may differ for compressive or tensile σ1. Without adequate experimental results, the currently suggested values12 are m=s=0.5, but as soon as the authors get to know relevant data, these parameters may be adjusted. Figure 7.
(σ1,σ2)-fracture curve including the σ1-influence on IFF.

Aiming on the stress exposures fEFF and fEIFF being the central parameters in the ηw1-definition also, the (σ2,σ1)-fracture curve may be transferred into a fEIFF(σ2) against fEFF(σ1) curve by dividing σ2 by R⊥ t or -R⊥ c and σ1 by R‖ t or -R‖ c, respectively. This operation results in solely positive values between [0;1] and now the former curves of quadrants 1 and 4 coincide in one curve valid for tensile σ1 and the former curves of quadrants 2 and 3 coincide in another curve valid for compressive σ1 – now both in the first quadrant. If compressive and tensile σ1 are treated equally regarding s and m, both remaining curves are identical, and for simplicity reasons, this case is shown in Figure 7.

Accepting the hypothesis above, that high σ1 – hence high FF stress exposure fEFF (cp. ‘Fibre fracture’ section) – weakens all the IFF fracture resistances of all the action planes in the same way, the considerations may be continued without distinction whether σ2 or any other combination of applied stresses leads to the IFF. Thus, the first quadrant of Figure 7 simultaneously shows the generally bearable fEIFF against fEFF. In order to stick to the general fracture condition fE=1, the bearable IFF stress exposure fEIFF is corrected by (ηw1)-1, which represents a reduction of the fracture resistances (25)fEIFFw1=fEIFF(θfp)ηw1

Setting fEIFF=1 (fracture condition) in equations (21) and (22) and multiplying all the fracture resistances of the action planes by the same ηw1-value, it may be brought to the left hand side, and accordingly, the first quadrant of Figure 7 also shows the value of ηw1 against fEFF. The weakening factor ηw1(fEFF) is now defined by an elliptical function for fEFF=[s;1] (26)ηw1(fEFF)=1-(fEFF-s)2a2 with a=1-s1-m2
Now that we have defined the conditions on the fracture curve, we address a general load case:

An ηw1-value is not only valid for a specific point on the fracture curve but it is applied to all the load cases whose proportional increase leads to that specific fracture (equation (25)). The set of these load cases forms a straight line in Figure 7(iii) with an equal ratio between fEIFF and fEFF. Accordingly the correlation ηw1(fEFF) has to be transferred into ηw1(fEIFF/fEFF). The relation between fEIFF/fEFF and fEFF is given by the fact that fEFF is the abscissa value of the intersection between the line and the segment of the ellipse (27)fEFF=s+s2-(1+a2c2)(s2-a2)1+a2c2 with c=fEIFF(θfp)fEFF
Equation (27) inserted into equation (26) the weakening factor is (28)ηw1(fEIFFfEFF)=c(ac2(a2-s2)+1+s)(ca)2+1 for 1s≥fEIFF(θfp)fEFF≥m
Note that for fEIFF(θfp)/fEFF>1/s, there is no σ1-influence (ηw1 = 1) while for fEIFF(θfp)/fEFF<m there is no IFF (p. 86).3

sec.title: Influence of nonfracture plane stresses on the IFF
sec.p: Micromechanical studies show that an IFF does not happen suddenly without any advance notice. Once the standardised IFF stress exposure (29)fEIFF '(θ)=fEIFF(θ)fEIFF(θfp) exceeds a threshold value of about fEIFF '(θ)≈0.5, instances of microdamage to the fibre-matrix composite will occur, which increase progressively with increasing stress exposure. In the example of a transverse/longitudinal shear stressing τ⊥‖, these are the familiar 45° microcracks (hackles),19 which are stopped at the fibres and cause tiny debondings. It is only when microfractures have exceeded, a certain magnitude that the IFF will suddenly occur. Generally, the microfractures resulting from one or more specific stressings have a weakening effect on the fracture resistances RA of all fibre-parallel sections.

Additionally, every real fibre–matrix composite contains flaws – in the form of curing cracks, flat air entrapments (voids) or local imperfections in the fibre-matrix bonding. Flaws of that kind do have a sense of direction. There is a high probability that a section with an orientation other than the theoretically defined θfp contains a flaw, which triggers the fracture despite its somewhat lower fEIFF(θ). This is a probabilistic effect. It adds uncertainty to the prediction of the fracture angle and causes the fracture stresses at IFF to be lower than those calculated following Mohr strictly.

In both examples, there is a mixture of effects of microdamage and of probabilistic effects – they cannot be treated separately. In the analysis, both effects are treated by a weakening factor ηm+p. Generalising, these examples lead to the following conclusion:

It is to be expected that the effects of microdamage and probabilistic reducing the magnitude of IFF stresses will rise with the number of fibre-parallel sections, which experience relatively high IFF stress exposures.

Figure 8 shows a comparison between standardised stress exposure curves (b) and the according ηm+p-effect on the IFF fracture curve (a): For stress combinations with relatively few sections in which fEIFF '(θ)>fEIFFthr ' (here = 0.5),12 there is only little impact of ηm+p (i), but there is a large effect for those combinations with many or all sections being over the threshold (ii). Note that the combination σ2=σ3 is the extreme case where all the sections are experiencing the same stress exposure (thus fEIFF '(θ)=1=constant). Figure 8.
For a (σ2,σ3)-stress combination: (a) fracture curves before (thin lines) and after ηm+p-correction (bold lines) and (b) standardised stress exposure curves fEIFF '(θ).

sec.title: Analytical treatment
sec.p:
Neither micromechanical failure analysis nor probabilistic methods can be included in an efficient component design process. Therefore, the following calculation method has been developed by Puck, which is applicable in engineering practice – it’s a phenomenological though physically founded approach. The ηm+p-correction is based on the following assumptions:
The IFF fracture plane appears at the angle θfp for which – according to Mohr’s hypothesis – the maximum stress exposure [fEIFF(θ)]max=fEIFF(θfp) has been calculated (cp. equations (21) and (22)).
The IFF fracture stresses are obtained by correcting the fracture stresses {σ}frMohr calculated from fEIFF(θfp) to lower stresses {σ}m+p using the correction factor ηm+p=[0;1] (equation (30)). Correspondingly, the IFF stress exposures calculated by Mohr fEIFF(θfp) are corrected to higher values fEIFFm+p by dividing them by ηm+p (equation (31)).
(30){σ}m+p={σ}frMohr·ηm+p={σ}fEIFF(θfp)·ηm+p={σ}fEIFFm+p (31)fEIFFm+p=fEIFF(θfp)ηm+por=fEIFFw1ηm+p,respectively

The integrated amount S of standardised stress exposure on all the relevant fibre-parallel sections represents the area below the respective fEIFF '(θ)-curve (Figure 8(b)) and is calculated as follows (32)S=∫allplanes *(fEIFF '(θ)-fEIFFthr ')dθ ≈∑0∘ 179∘*(fEIFF '(θ)-fEIFFthr ')·Δθ*only> >including> >planes> >wheref'EIFF(θ)≥f'EIFFthr

The summing formula as presented above is valid for angular increments of Δθ=1∘. The integration or summing with a zero line shifted by fEIFFthr ' results in a considerably higher weight of high fEIFF '(θ)-values than of low ones.
Puck has described the dependence of ηm+p on the integrated standardised stress exposure S by (33)ηm+p=1-ΔmaxS-SrefSmax-SrefwithSmax=90∘andSref=30∘.13
The reference value Sref achieves a reasonable sensitivity on ηm+p against the differences in the S-values of different states of stress. The value Δmax=[0.15;0.25] calibrates the ηm+p-correction.

Note that {σ}frMohr and fEIFF(θfp) (equations (30) and (31)) have to be calculated by a corrected set of material parameters. The reason is that the experimentally determined strengths R⊥ t, R⊥ c and R⊥‖ (the anchor points of the IFF criteria) ab initio include microdamage and probabilistic effects. Thus, the analytical procedure of the ηm+p-corrections should not degrade these values second time – the experimentally measured basic material strengths have just to be met by an analysis including ηm+p!

Correcting the material strengths suggests the correction of the inclination parameters p⊥‖ t,c and p⊥⊥ t,c, too. This matter is discussed in detail in Knops (p. 94ff),3 but up to now, the experimental data are limited to (σ2,τ21)-fracture curves, which prove the following correction for p⊥‖ c (34)p⊥‖cor cp⊥‖ c=1+0.6·Δmaxp⊥‖ cfor0.15≤Δmax≤0.25and0.25≤p⊥‖ c≤0.35
The remaining inclination parameters p⊥‖ t and p⊥⊥ t,c stay unmodified for the time being.
The corrected strengths R⊥cor t, R⊥cor c and R⊥‖cor on which a fracture analysis including the ηm+p-corrections has to be based are derived by (35)Rcor=Rηm+p

The ηm+p-values in the denominator have to be calculated from the respective load cases – uniaxial tension σ⊥ t, uniaxial compression σ⊥ c and pure in-plane shear τ⊥‖ – by equations (32) and (33). The fact that the calculation of the fEIFF '(θ)-values should already be based on corrected strengths reveals a circular reference. In general, this prohibits a closed-form solution but the problem may easily be solved using contemporary numerical software. The problem of the indluence of ηm+p has been addressed recently by Correa et al.,18 where Boundary Element methods were employed in conjuction with Interfacial Fracture Mechanics concepts. They examine the effect of the interfibre/matrix failure under biaxial transverse loadings using micromechanical formulations.

Regarding the pure in-plane shear case τ⊥‖, such a procedure can be omitted due to the fact that τ⊥‖(θ)=cos(θ)·τ21 is the only stress component on any action plane. Using the standardised stress exposure in equation (32), the values R⊥‖ or R⊥‖cor are of no importance and S⊥‖=39,24∘ exclusively results from the integration of the cosine shape of fEIFF '(θ) independent from the material. The result is the value R⊥‖cor, which exactly meets the fracture condition fEIFFm+p=1 for an applied in-plane shear of τ21=R⊥‖.

The uniaxial compression case may be simplified accordingly: Using equation (6) and assuming an unmodified p⊥⊥ c, the compressive strength R⊥ c remains the only material parameter and vanishes after the standardisation (equation (29)). Hence, the value S⊥ c depends on p⊥⊥ c only and is about 36° for the suggested values of p⊥⊥ c (Table 1). The resulting R⊥cor c leads to fEIFFm+p=1 for an applied σ2=-R⊥ c. Equation (6) provides the associated R⊥⊥cor A.

Only in case of a uniaxial tension, there are more than one mutually independent material parameters relevant in equation (21) and the shape of fEIFF '(θ) depends on both, R⊥⊥cor A and R⊥cor t (assuming an unmodified p⊥⊥ t). However, using the R⊥⊥cor A defined in the step above, an R⊥cor t can be found, which leads to fEIFFm+p=1 for an applied σ2=R⊥ t. The ηm+p-influence for this load case is expected to be rather small and may be neglected if no adequate numerical software is at hand. In general, it is highly advisible to use the ηm+p-corrections. Even if based on uncorrected material parameters, the IFF prediction including ηm+p will be more accurate than any analysis neglecting the influence of microdamage and probabilistics.

sec.title: Fibre fracture
sec.p:
Puck’s theory clearly distinguishes between the two fracture types of a UD lamina: IFF and FF. In an elementary approach, those two cases are treated with mutually independent criteria, where the FF criterion represents two simple stress limits for the tension and compression mode (Figure 9). Figure 9.
Fibre failure modes of a unidirectional-composite, from Puck.15

By definition, the lamina is treated as a homogenised orthotropic continuum, thus the stress exposure fEFF with regard to FF is defined as a ratio between homogenised stress σ1 in the lamina (not in the fibre) parallel to the fibre direction and the tension or compression stress at fracture of the lamina in fibre direction R‖ t and -R‖ c, respectively (equation (36)). FF is predicted for any of the two values by fEFF=1. Please note that all strength parameters are defined as positive values (36)fEFF={σ1R‖ tforσ1>0σ1(-R‖ c)forσ1<0

While these maximum stress criteria have been generally approved by extensive experimental work,20 there are findings that suggest more sophisticated FF criteria.4,5 Although this is an ongoing matter (p. 16ff),3 there are applicable formulations covering the influence of transverse – particularly compressive – stress18,21 and shear,22 whereas the former does have a significantly larger impact on FF. Analysing 3D states of stress, it is therefore highly recommended to account for the transverse effect in the following way:
The fundamental hypothesis for UD laminae is:4,5,15
The maximum sustainable longitudinal stresses σ1f acting in the fibres are the same whether the FF occurs under combined (σ1,σ2,σ3) or uniaxial (exclusively σ1) stresses.

In contrast, the homogenised longitudinal stresses in the UD lamina at FF do differ whether combined or uniaxial stress is applied because the two cases lead to different longitudinal stresses σ1f in the fibre. The reason is that transverse stresses (σ2 and/or σ3) – due to a Poisson’s effect – do influence the strain in the fibre direction. The effect is locally enlarged due to the inhomogeneously distributed stress in the matrix: Close to the fibre, the transverse stress is higher than the homogenised value on the lamina-level. Puck accounts for this stress magnification by the use of a magnification factor mσf and proposes the values 1.3 for GFRC and 1.1 for CFRC.15,20

The starting point for the corresponding analysis is the strain ɛ1f in the fibres due to the combined stresses (σ1,σ2,σ3) (37)ɛ1f=σ1fE ‖f-ν ‖⊥fE⊥f·mσf·(σ2+σ3) With (38)ν ‖⊥fE⊥f=ν⊥‖fE ‖f and ɛ1f=ɛ1 the longitudinal stress in the fibres σ1f is (39)σ1f=E ‖f·ɛ1+ν⊥‖f·mσf·(σ2+σ3)

From equation (39), a new fracture condition can be derived. First, ε1 is replaced by the elastic law of the UD lamina (40)ɛ1=σ1E‖-ν⊥‖E‖·(σ2+σ3) then the fibre stress σ1f by the strength of the fibre R ‖f (41)R ‖f=E ‖f·ɛFFf and R‖=E‖·ɛFFFinally, withɛFFf=ɛFF that> >leads> >to R ‖f=E ‖fE‖·R‖.
The resulting FF condition for a UD lamina is (42)1±R‖ t,c[σ1-(ν⊥‖-ν⊥‖f·mσfE‖E ‖f)(σ2+σ3)]=1 with {R‖ tfor[…]≥0-R‖ cfor[…]<0

The fracture function is homogeneous of grade 1 and, thus, can directly be understood as a formulation for the stress exposure fEFF of a UD lamina with regard to FF (43)fEFF=1±R‖ t,c[σ1-(ν⊥‖-ν⊥‖ f·mσfE‖E‖f)(σ2+σ3)] fE=12(∑L+(∑L)2+4∑Q)

Please note that ν⊥‖ and ν⊥‖f are the major Poisson’s ratios of the UD lamina and the fibres, respectively. The first index denotes the direction of the lateral strain caused by the stress acting in the direction of the second index.

Puck has found that, in case of plane (σ1,σ2,τ21)-stress, the results of equations (36) and (43) differ by only a few percent. However, the influence of transverse stresses on FF can become important in the region of combined compressive σ2 c and σ3 c of similar magnitude, where |σ2| and |σ3| can exceed the transverse compressive strength R⊥ c by a factor of up to 4 (cp. Test Case 5 section).21

sec.title: Applications of Puck’s criteria on isotropic material
sec.p:
The fundamental difference between fracture of a UD composite and an isotropic pure matrix material is that, in the latter case, the fracture may occur in a plane at any orientation (θ,ϕ) (Figure 10). In a UD composite, fracture may only occur in planes parallel to the fibres and thus one angle θ unambiguously defines possible fracture planes (cp. Figure 3). Figure 10.
Definition of an arbitrary action plane. Figure 11.
FE representation of the laminate. FE: finite element.

Therefore, in the isotropic case, the stresses acting on an action plane are σn(θ,ϕ) and τnΨ(θ,ϕ). Once these stresses are calculated from the applied stresses,23 the search for the plane with the largest stress exposure may be performed using a slightly modified formulation of the usual fE now depending on (θ,ϕ):

In an isotropic material, there are no different fracture resistances of the action plane against the two shear stresses τn1 and τnt and accordingly R⊥⊥ A and R⊥‖ A can be replaced by RAτ. That means that, in the isotropic case, just one fracture resistance of the action plane against shear has to be derived from the measured strengths of the material. The value for the isotropic fracture resistance against shear can be easily derived in the style of equation (6) using the compressive strength of the material Rc (44)RAτ=Rc2(1+pc)

This approach is consistent with the fact that the transverse-transverse direction of a UD lamina is its isotropic direction. Accordingly, the proposed values of p⊥⊥ t,c12 are used as benchmark to define the only set of inclination parameters left p⊥⊥ t,c=p⊥‖ t,c=pt,c. If the isotropic material behaves intrinsically brittle (cp. ‘Puck’s action plane-related IFF-criteria’ section), the considerations that led to the fracture resistance of the action plane against tension (cp. equation (4)) are still valid and RAt=Rt. Otherwise, RAt is a parameter of the fracture criteria whose definition demands more effort (see ‘Test Case 1’ section).

The interpolation for the inclination parameters in equation (23) is now obsolete, and with equation (1), the definitions of the stress exposure fE(θ,ϕ) (cp. equations (21) and (22)) become (45)fE(θ,ϕ)=[(1RAt-ptRAτ)σn(θ,ϕ)]2+(τnΨ(θ,ϕ)RAτ)2 +ptRAτσn(θ,ϕ) for σn≥0 and (46)fE(θ,ϕ)=(τnΨ(θ,ϕ)RAτ)2+(pcRAτσn(θ,ϕ))2+pcRAτσn(θ,ϕ) for σn<0.
For the sake of simplicity, we will assume in the following pc=pt=p.

The procedure above leads to a rotationally symmetric MFB (cp. Figure 6(a)) with identical longitudinal sections for any angle Ψ. This representation equals the reduction of the MFB to a Master Fracture Curve (cp. Figure 6(c)) depending only on σn and τnΨ as it was stated for isotropic materials in the very beginning (cp. ‘Puck’s theory section’). It goes without saying that, in isotropic material, neither the x1-direction does have the usual exceptional position nor the FF criterion is of any significance.

sec.title: Failure and post-failure behaviour prediction using FEA
sec.p: While analytical algorithms like CLT are most efficiently used for the prediction of in-plane behaviour, 3D stressings clearly exceed their applicability. Although there are analytical approaches to the 3D-stress analysis of laminates, closed form solutions are only known for few specific cases of rectangular laminates under sinusoidal transverse load.24 FEA, however, provides a wide variety of elements not only for 3D stress analysis in laminate components but also for the analysis of thermal residual stresses.

Aiming at the prediction of the general material behaviour at an isolated point of the lamina or laminate, the present FEA model needs no discretisation along the two in-plane directions. As there are no bending load cases given and all the given laminates are symmetric, we expect homogeneous states of stress throughout the lamina’s thickness direction, thus only one element per lamina is sufficient (Figure 11). Though commercial FE packages offer various shell elements for the representation of lamina and laminate structures, their 3D capabilities in terms of stress results are still limited. Thus, the present model uses fully integrated linear volume elements whose loading and boundary conditions are described in ‘Geometric nonlinearity’ and ‘RVE approach to derive laminate behaviour’ sections, respectively.

sec.title: Implementation of Puck’s theory in ABAQUS
sec.p: The latter is a six by six matrix, which represents the incremental change of every stress component for an incremental change of every strain component. As the nonlinear solver of ABAQUS is based on such tangent moduli, the definition of the Jacobian matrix is the crucial factor for the stability of the analysis. The Finite Element Method achieves the equilibrium by varying the displacement of the nodes. The task of the material model is then to output the related stresses.

sec.title: Nonlinear constitutive behaviour
sec.p: In the case of WWFE-II, we included the nonlinear constitutive behaviour for in-plane shear, transverse shear in 1-3-direction and for transverse and through-thickness compression. We ignored those nonlinearities where the individual behaviour of the fibre and matrix was given solely. The nonlinear behaviour is commonly entered by the given pointwise correlation between stresses and strains. Generated from uniaxial experiments, these curves end at the fracture due to uniaxial load. Loaded multiaxially, the material possibly bears much higher stresses, which widely exceed the given stress–strain relations. The easiest way to ensure that the user material subroutine (UMAT) can still correlate a valid stress to a given strain increment (cp. ‘Implementation of Puck’s theory in ABAQUS’ section) is the extrapolation of the given curve by its last gradient. This approach is implemented in all the material models and represents the basic solution of the problem. As it is completely unphysical and clearly overestimates the resulting strains, the following considerations are necessary.

With regard to the coupling between transverse and shear deformation, Puck and Mannigel25 presented the finding resulted in two analytical relations for γ21(τ21,σ2) and ɛ2(σ2,τ21). These curves perfectly reproduce the experimental results for the stress ratios under consideration σ2/|τ21|=[-2;1] and are valid up to fracture due to combined load. The physical background of this approach is the idea that nonlinearities in fibre/polymer composites result from cumulative micromechanical damage.21 If a combined load leads to higher bearable stresses in terms of macroscopic fracture, it is reasonable to expect the influence of microdamage also being shifted to higher stress levels. Mainly based on the ratios between the stress exposure due to uniaxial load fE (τ21) or fE (σ2), respectively, and the stress exposure due to the combined load fE, the approach is generally transferable into 3D space.

According to Puck’s failure theory, the presented approach is stress based and, therefore, not directly applicable for FEA (cp. ‘Implementation of Puck’s theory in ABAQUS’ section). Additionally, under 3D loading, the IFF stresses can exceed the uniaxial fracture stresses by factors far beyond the verified interval of the presented approach. Hence, it is not yet implemented in the FEA routine but its analytical curves act as a reference for the applied self-similar scaling of the given stress–strain curves. In the present case, the self-similarity is achieved by scaling every point on the curve along its secant modulus by a common factor (cp. Figure 12). In case of a lamina, the bearable applied load is mostly independent from its deformation, and it is sufficient to scale the given stress–strain relation up to the failure stress after the analysis (cp. ‘Test Case 4’ section). In case of a laminate failure analysis, the bearable applied load is depending on the constitutive behaviour of the different laminae. Therefore, the failure analysis should be based on stress–strain relations, which are scaled to the strain at IFF – which is a result of that very analysis. This fact emphasises the need for an iterative adjustment of the respective stress–strain relation. Figure 12 exemplarily shows the σ3(ɛ3)-relation on which the failure analysis of Test Case 12 is based on. It is scaled up to ɛ3=-0.065, which is about the strain at the predicted IFF. Figure 12.
Scaled self-similar constitutive behaviour in through-thickness direction for Test Case 12 (residual stresses neglected).

sec.title: Residual stresses
sec.p: UD fibre-reinforced laminae show orthotropic behaviour in terms of thermal expansion. In the process of curing, this leads to residual stresses in the final laminate. The process is chemically and thermodynamically challenging; influences like tempering history, ambient pressure and humidity are hardly to cover in a structural mechanics context. However, the representation by a simple cooling from stress free temperature to room temperature using linear thermal coefficients is intuitive but overestimates the resulting residual stresses according to our experience.4,5 Puck assumes the true residual stresses to reach half the values calculated from this approach. Accordingly, the analysis is based on half the temperature drop from the stress-free temperature to ambient temperature. Note that, in the case of FEA, the thermally induced residual stresses are automatically subject to the nonlinear constitutive behaviour of the material.

sec.title: Geometric nonlinearity
sec.p: A static FEA offers two ways of forming the equilibrium – geometrically linear based on the original geometry or nonlinear based on the actual geometry. Expecting large deformations a geometrically nonlinear calculation is highly recommendable, and this option automatically includes the influences due to the change of fibre direction during the loading process. Choosing this option, an originally pure shear loading (τ21 for example) does not result in pure shear stress in the deformed state. Puck and Matthias Deuschle26 provides details of the effects of specimen geometry on the predcition of the model.

sec.title: In situ effect
sec.p: The transverse compressive strength R⊥2 c and the through-thickness strengths including shear (R⊥3 t/c and R⊥‖31) are assumed to be unaffected. While the present implementation accounts for different values for R⊥2 t and R⊥3 t (cp. ‘Test Cases 6 and 7’ section), it enforces R⊥‖21=R⊥‖31. Furthermore, the present implementation does not yet distinguish between embedded and outer plies, although it is known that the in situ effect on outer plies is smaller if not negligible. Taking into account the in situ effect by increasing the strengths of materials is another case where the given nonlinear stress–strain relations are exceeded as they end at the original strengths. Thus, the affected curves have been scaled in a self-similar way according to ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section.

sec.title: RVE approach to derive laminate behaviour
sec.p: While the present implementation aims on the analysis of whole structures in the long term, the laminate Test Cases of the WWFE-II require the prediction of a material behaviour valid at single material points. RVE are an established approach to derive the homogenised constitutive behaviour of inhomogeneous materials.28,29 By definition, the RVE is large enough to incorporate all the inhomogeneities of the material while being small enough for being considered as a single point when regarding the whole structure. For the purpose of homogenisation, the imagination of an endless row of identical RVEs is used, which results in periodic boundary conditions for each single RVE. In the case of laminates, we consider through-thickness inhomogeneities (namely the layer composition, see Figure 11) and derive through-thickness homogenised results, which represent the constitutive and damage behaviour of the entire laminate.

sec.title: Successive damage evolution – degradation
sec.p: In the context of postfailure analysis, it is important to stress that Puck’s failure criteria predict macroscopic failure through the entire ply. The stress exposure fE=1 denotes the state of stress in a lamina where the first macroscopic crack through the respective lamina occurs. In case of a laminate, reaching a lamina’s fracture condition is not equivalent with the disintegration of the whole material and the state of stress is labelled as initial failure stress. A further deformation starts a successive damage evolution process in the form of a growing crack density. Accounting for these cracks in a smeared way results in the reduction of the stiffness of the respective lamina – this process is called degradation.

Depending on the load and laminate composition, the loading of the entire laminate may be further increased while individual laminae are already in the process of degradation. This is the case if the applied load can be redistributed from the degrading lamina to neighbouring laminae with higher load-bearing capacities. The maximum bearable stress of a laminate is not reached before the strongest lamina reaches its failure condition. The related state of stress is understood as final failure stress.

Load redistribution from weaker to stronger laminae is excluded in cases where any load has to be transmitted in through-thickness direction of the laminate (σz,τxz and τyz namely) or where all the laminae are experiencing equal stress exposures. In these cases, a lamina cannot dispose of any load reducing its stiffness. From the numerical point of view, the smallest further increase of the applied load does lead to an immediate increase of the crack density up to infinity. Neglecting damping or statistical effects, in theses cases, the curves of initial and final failure stress coincide.

After reaching the final failure stress, there are laminate and load configurations, which allow a further deformation of the material at constant or declining applied loads before it completely disintegrates. As Puck’s theory is stress based on the one hand and the definition of a complete disintegration is arguable on the other hand, we do not provide a final failure strain information in these cases.

A special case occurs for damage due to compressive σ2 and/or σ3 in a lamina because the resulting cracks are still capable of transmitting compressive forces in the respective directions. In these cases, the lamina does transmit increasing applied stresses after exceeding the IFF fracture criterion up to a point where the laminate starts breaking or fragmenting. Both effects are ruled by mechanisms on a microscopic level far below the capabilities of a smeared crack representation and a continuum-based constitutive model. The ongoing effort of covering such damage evolutions by granular media-based simulations30 has not reached a level of applicability to classify the processes as a predictable – hence tolerable – damage evolution. As long as this is not the case, we consider the limits of application having been reached when the stress exposure in one or more laminae reaches fE=1.

Regarding the WWFE-II, none of the Test Cases meets the above mentioned requirements for a reliable postfailure analysis. Where the Test Cases ask for failure stresses (cp. ‘Test Case 8 and Test Cases 10 and 11’ sections), the initial and final failure curves following the above definition coincide. Only a few load cases of Test Case 8 are considered to reach a final fibre failure after an initial interfibre failure. In Test Case 9 (cp. ‘Test Case 9’ section), all laminae are experiencing an equal stress exposure, and in Test Case 12 (cp. ‘Test Case 12’ section), the applied pressure σz leads to damage resulting from compressive σ3 in the lamina.

Where the analysis of postfailure degradation is appropriate, the growing crack density is represented by a stiffness reduction of the respective lamina. As long as advanced proposals of a decreasing bearable IFF stress exposure31 are not yet transferred into 3D space, the degradation process is ruled by the existing assumption4,5 (47)fEIFFw1=1=constant

The requirement is met by the successive reduction of the layer’s normal- and shear-stiffnesses when a load increment starts to result in stress exposures greater than 1. Reducing these stiffnesses results – for a given state of strain – in declining stresses and accordingly a declining stress exposure. When fE has dropped to the value 1, the necessary amount of degradation δ is reached (equation (48)). The resulting change in the lamina’s stiffness leads to a different overall load distribution in the laminate. This is the starting point of an iterative, highly nonlinear numerical procedure required by that kind of degradation method.

Extensive experimental work has revealed that the normal-stiffness is affected more strongly by a growing crack density than the shear stiffness, whereas the difference depends on the kind of lamina (GFRC/CFRC).32,33 While the obtained rules are successfully applied for plain problems,4,5 there are no experimental investigations covering 3D effects or the expected influence of the fracture plane orientation.

The present implementation is based on preliminary considerations34 and the assumption that the G-moduli experience only 0.6 times the reduction of the E-moduli. The fracture angle-dependent degradation breakdown on the orthotropic elastic constants of the lamina follows an intuitive scheme (Table 4) resulting in a simple degradation rule (48)Ei>deg=Ei·(1-δ·Table> 4)Gij>deg=Gij·(1-δ·0.6·Table> 4)
Table 4.
Breakdown of the degradation depending on the fracture angle
E1 = 0 G12: cosθfp
E2: cosθfp G13: sinθfp
E3: sinθfp G23:1

The value δ=[0;1] represents the progress of the degradation. Starting at δ=0 (undamaged material), it has to be successively increased to meet equation (47) during the following load increments. Defining a δmax offers the possibility to represent a residual stiffness of the lamina once a saturated crack density is reached.35 In that context, δ may also be interpreted as a measure for the macroscopic crack density in a degrading lamina. Knops,3 VDI-Gesellschaft Kunststofftechnik,12 Puck and Matthias Deuschle,31 Knops and Bögle33 and Lambrecht35 provide further details.

The reduction process is valid when σn > 0. When a negative σn acts on the action plane, the crack sides will continue to transmit that compressive stress. In these cases, there will be no reduction of the E-moduli, and the applied load may be increased until a different failure mode is activated.

sec.title: Results of the WWFE-II Test Cases
sec.p: The current method is employed to predict the response of 12 Test Cases provided by the organisers of the WWFE-II. These Test Cases cover various materials (including a polymer material, unidirectional laminae and a number of multidirectional laminates) made from glass/epoxy and carbon/epoxy. The cases include full 3D loadings and further details of material properties, lay-ups and loadings as well as guidelines are described in Kaddour and Hinton.7

The following results of the Test Cases have been obtained by applying the given stress ratios in the sense of nominal values. This means that the applied forces leading to the stresses are related to the undeformed geometry and are kept constant in value and direction during the deformation while the area of application and/or the direction of the material’s orthotropic axis will change. This results in differences between the applied nominal stress value and the true state of stress in the deformed material (cp. ‘Geometric nonlinearity’ section). Note that this is an assumption, not a requirement arising from the application of FEA. Using FEA, we are free to choose whether the load direction follows the material rotation or not, whether the applied stresses are meant to be related to the undeformed or deformed geometry or else, to neglect all those effects and run a geometrically linear analysis.

Regarding the presented fracture angles θfp, it is important to note that, in all the load cases, the loads are applied symmetrically against the orthotropic axis of the failing lamina. In these cases, the action planes at θ and 180∘-θ analytically experience the same stress exposures fEIFF. Which of the two orientations is reported as θfp depends on numerical inaccuracies.

The analyses have been run using the material parameters provided in Kaddour and Hinton.7 The orthotropic constitutive behaviour of every single UD lamina is characterised by its homogenised Young’s moduli E1,E2 and E3, its shear moduli G12,G13 and G23 and the three Poisson’s ratios ν12,ν13 and ν23. The transverse and through-thickness moduli E2 and E3 (in the compressive domain) and the in-plane and transverse shear moduli G12 and G13 are derived as secant moduli from the given nonlinear stress–strain curves. Thermal expansion is considered orthotropically by α1,α2 and α3. The necessary input for the actual failure analysis is limited to few UD lamina strengths – the longitudinal tensile and compressive strengths R‖ t and R‖ c, the transverse tensile and compressive strength R⊥ t and R⊥ c (if different from through-thickness direction then R⊥2 t,R⊥2 c,R⊥3 t,R⊥3 c) and the in-plane shear strength R⊥‖. To apply the advanced FF criterion (cp. ‘Fibre fracture’ section), the fibres’ longitudinal Young’s modulus E‖ f and Poisson’s ratio ν⊥‖f are needed additionally. The rest of the parameters follow the default values3,12 and, therefore, are not considered as input parameters.

sec.title: Test Case 1
sec.p: While intrinsically brittle behaviour (cp. ‘Puck’s action plane-related IFF-criteria’ section) may be assumed for most FRCs, the present pure matrix material needs further consideration. For MY750, the given shear strength Rτ=54MPa is considerably lower than the given tensile strength Rt=80MPa. Applied shear stress leads to a maximum tensile stress σn t of equal magnitude on a section inclined by 45°. So, if the given material was intrinsically brittle, then Rτ would be close or equal to Rt and this section would be the fracture plane. As this is obviously not the case here, fracture is probably driven by a mixed-mode stressing (σn,τnΨ) on the fracture plane. Having detected this behaviour for an applied pure shear stress, there is no reason to expect exclusively σn t-driven fractures due to an applied uniaxial tensile stress – a mixed-mode fracture on a section inclined against the action plane of the applied uniaxial tension will probably occur. Thus, equation (4) is no longer valid, and there are now two unknowns, mutually dependent model parameters to determine: p and RAt.

As the calibration of the model demands the determination of two parameters, we use those two given states of stress leading to fracture (σt=Rt and τ=Rτ), which have not yet been incorporated into any other relation (σc=-Rc is already used in equation (44)). For both cases, it is possible to determine the set of value pairs (RAt,p) where the model exactly predicts the given failure stresses for uniaxial tension and pure shear (Figure 13). The use of an analytical tool is the most efficient way to derive the presented chart.36 Based on the parameters met by both curves (Figure 13), the results of Test Case 1 are summarised in Figure 14. Figure 13.
Determination of the model parameters RAt and p in case of not intrinsically brittle, isotropic material. Figure 14.
Results of Test Case 1 (a) and close-up (b) indicating the orientation of the fracture plane θfp and the normal stress on the fracture plane σn, results before (thin) and after ηm+p-correction (bold lines).

In Figure 14, there is only one angle θfp denoted defining the orientation of the fracture plane while the second one φfp is arbitrary. The prediction of the second angle in space is impossible since the applied stressing is rotationally symmetric around the x-axis and thus all sections rotated around that axis experience the same stress exposure. In case of σx=σy=σz (Figure 14(ii)), both angles θfp and φfp are arbitrary.

Looking at the results without ηm+p-correction (thin lines), note that the tensile cut-off in the first quadrant takes place at slightly higher stresses 82.67MPa=RAt than the given tensile strength Rt=80MPa (Figure 14(b)(i)). Apparently, there do exist tensile fractures, which occur in the section of maximum tensile stress σn t=RAt, although we have stated that we are dealing with a not intrinsically brittle material here. The reason for this is the proximity of these stressings to the hydrostatic situation towards which the shear stresses τnΨ on arbitrary sections tend to zero.

Including the ηm+p-correction (cp. ‘Influence of nonfracture plane stresses on the IFF’ section), the analysis has to be based on the corrected values Rcor t, Rcor c and pcor. As the fracture due to applied pure compression is independent from Rcor t and – in the present case – not very sensitive against the variation of p, this case is used to calibrate the Rcor c-value first. Then, the values for Rcor t and pcor are calibrated according to the method described above (cp. Figure 13). The corrected values are Rcor t=95.5 MPa, Rcor c=123.71 MPa and pcor=0.073. The resulting fracture curve does no longer exhibit the completely unphysical sharp edge in the first quadrant (cp. Figure 8, ‘Influence of nonfracture plane stresses on the IFF’ section). Note that the ηm+p-correction may lead to slightly higher failure stresses in some cases.

It is worth pointing out that Puck’s failure criteria were developed for highly composite lamina where fibre failure in direction 1 is largely independent from the interfibre failure modes (IFF). The application of that philosophy to isotropic material is strictly not valid. Consequently, the fracture angles shown in Figure 14 may be un-realistic. Further discussion is made in Puck and Matthias Deuschle.26

sec.title: Test Case 2
sec.p:
The result of Test Case 2 (Figure 15) is the fracture curve of a UD carbon/epoxy lamina for varied ratios of the applied shear stress τ21 and normal stresses σ1=σ2=σ3. Continuing through Test Cases 3 and 4, these cases address the effect of hydrostatic pressure on the mechanical properties of a lamina.37 In the tensile regime, the applied state of stress leads to transverse fractures due to tensile σn on the respective fracture plane. These fractures are promoted by additional τn1 due to the applied τ21. In the compressive regime, the equal amount of σ2 and σ3 excludes fractures due to τnt on any action plane (cp. equation (3)). At the same time, the bearable τn1 rises with increasing compressive stress σn c on the fracture plane resulting in a high amount of bearable τ21 if it is combined with high σ2=σ3-values. For a decreasing ratio between τ21 and compressive σ1=σ2=σ3, the failure mode eventually changes to FF due to compressive σ1. Using the extended FF criterion (cp. ‘Fibre fracture’ section), the lamina bears more compressive σ1 than the given longitudinal compressive strength R‖ c=950 MPa. The according true FF stress is -1463 MPa, which is reached at the plotted nominal value of -1165 MPa. Figure 15.
Results of Test Case 2 for two different clamping situations: the fibre-perpendicular side clamped allows fibre rotation, the fibre-parallel clamping prevents fibre rotation.

Although having stated that a compressive σ2=σ3 does not lead to an IFF according to the application of Puck’s theory, which predicts – by definition – macroscopic fracture, there are experimental findings that microdamage starts at σ2=σ3≈-2R⊥ c. This conclusion has been drawn from acoustic emission studies,21 but the prediction of these microdamages merging to a macroscopic crack30 is still a challenging task and far beyond engineering application. Hence, the corresponding thresholds are included (cp. ‘Test Case 5 and Test Cases 6 and 7’ sections) for information only but there is the possibility that microdamages merge to macroscopic IFF before the predicted failures at high hydrostatic pressures may occur.

The high amount of bearable τ21 leads to a considerable change in fibre direction if permitted by the applied boundary conditions. For the nominal hydrostatic pressure of -600 MPa, the γ21-results of Test Case 4 (Figure 17) provide the magnitude of the fibres’ rotation. Rotations of that magnitude increase the discrepancy between applied nominal stresses and the true stresses on which the failure analysis is based on. Therefore, the plot shows the results for two different boundary conditions where either the (x1,x3)- or the (x2,x3)-plane of the material is fixed in space. Regarding the FF, the bearable σ1 slightly increases with rotated fibres because now σ1 is only partly acting in the fibre’s longitudinal direction. Figure 16.
Results of Test Case 3 for the two different clamping situations. Figure 17.
Results of Test Case 4, the clamping allows fibre rotation.

Note that, in the present case of a geometrically nonlinear analysis, the constitutive behaviour influences the stress results as they are derived from the deformed geometry (cp. ‘Geometric nonlinearity’ section). As the bearable shear stresses are considerably above those bearable under a pure τ21-loading, the given nonlinear τ21(γ21)-relation is exceeded. In such cases, we have proposed the use of a self-similarly scaled stress–strain relation (cp. ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section). However, in the present case of rather small nonlinearities in the given τ21(γ21)-relation, the effort of a separate iteration for every point on the fracture curve seems not rewarding; hence, we decided to step back to a linear τ21(γ21)-relation for Test Cases 2 and 3.

sec.title: Test Case 3
sec.p: The result of Test Case 3 shows the γ21-values of the fractures predicted for Test Case 2 in both clamping cases (Figure 16). The shown strain values are expected to be slightly lower than if calculated following the iterative approach for nonlinear stress–strain relations (cp. ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ and ‘Test Case 2’ sections). This fact can also be discovered by comparing the failure strains of Test Cases 3 and 4 (Figure 16(i)).

sec.title: Test Case 4
sec.p: The result of Test Case 4 (Figure 17) is a τ21(γ21)-curve after the application of a σ1=σ2=σ3=-600 MPa preload on the same lamina as used in Test Cases 2 and 3. As stated above, the compressive σ2=σ3 does not lead to any τnt on either of the action planes but leads to a constant compressive σn=σ2=σ3 for any action plane orientation θ.

As compressive σn adds a portion to the intrinsic fracture resistance of the action plane against shear – here R⊥‖ A is of importance only – the applied preload can be represented by adding an induced fracture resistance σn·p⊥‖ c to R⊥‖ A if analytically calculated. However, in FEA it is no problem to include a load history and thus the existing routine needs no modification. Both approaches result in a bearable shear of τ21=252 MPa. In contrast to Test Case 3, we applied the iterative scaling of the τ21(γ21)-relation for this particular load case (cp. ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section), and Figure 17 shows the predicted nonlinear behaviour.

sec.title: Test Case 5
sec.p:
The results of Test Case 5 form a fracture curve of a glass/epoxy lamina for varied combinations of σ2 and σ3=σ1 (Figure 18). It is dominated by IFFs, FFs only occur close to the axis of hydrostatic pressure. The fact that the IFF part of the curve has no discontinuities is due to the application of ηm+p (cp. ‘Influence of nonfracture plane stresses on the IFF’ section and Figure 8). The result figure includes a comparison between the simple FF criterion where only σ1 is decisive and the improved criterion (cp. ‘Fibre fracture’ section). In the latter case, the additional stresses in the fibre due to the different Poisson’s ratios in the matrix and the fibre are considered, thus the FF shows a dependence on the applied transverse stresses. The dependence visible in the case of the simple FF criterion is due to geometric nonlinearities only (cp. ‘Geometric nonlinearity’ section). The threshold for microdamage is included for information only (cp. ‘Test Case 2’ section) but points out the possibility that microdamages merge to macroscopic IFF before the predicted FF may occur. Figure 18.
Results of Test Case 5 indicating the fracture angle θfp [°]: comparison between simple and extended fibre fracture criterion.

sec.title: Test Cases 6 and 7
sec.p: The results of Test Cases 6 and 7 are the fracture curves of a glass/epoxy and carbon/epoxy lamina for varied combinations of σ1 and σ2=σ3 (Figures 19 and 20). These curves clearly show the effect of ηw1: The fracture resistance of the matrix declines with high fibre parallel σ1 stresses applied (cp. ‘Influences of fibre-parallel stress σ1 on the IFF’ section). The curve is open in the negative σ2=σ3-regime. As stated before, this stress combination cannot produce a fracture predictable by a macroscopic model (cp. ‘Test Case 2’ section). Accordingly, both branches of the curve might be continued into σ2=σ3=-∞ but such an extension of the shown negative σ2=σ3-regime does not provide any information about the expected failure. However, we know from experiments21 that these states of stress do result in microscopic damage as soon as a value of -2R⊥ c is exceeded. This is the case beyond σ2=σ3=-360 MPa for Test Case 6 and -300 MPa for Test Case 7. The quantification of these effects and the transformation into an applicable prediction approach are ongoing issues (cp. ‘Test Case 2’ section). In this context arises the question when the lamina fails under hydrostatic pressure. As a compressive σ2=σ3 does not produce a predictable macroscopic fracture, the longitudinal compressive strength theoretically is the limiting parameter. This study reveals that an action-plane related fracture criterion (here the IFF criterion) will not predict any failure under hydrostatic pressure whereas a stress limit (here FF criterion) will. Accordingly, there is no prediction regarding the hydrostatic failure of Test Case 1 (see ‘Test Case 1’ section) as the isotropic material is treated by the IFF criterion only.
