Whether – in the lamina Test Cases – the predicted FF is reached experimentally depends on how fast the growing microdamages merge to a macroscopic IFF beyond σ1=σ2=σ3=-2R⊥ c.30 This process is expected to be highly dependent on the experimental setup.

Regarding the FFs, please note that the lines are not vertical – the reason is the extended FF-criterion with its dependence on transverse stresses. The comparison between the FFs of Test Cases 6 and 7 reveals a stronger dependence in case of glass FRC (Figure 19). This is the result of a larger magnification factor mσf for GFRC (1.3) than for CFRC (1.1, cp. ‘Fibre fracture’ section).

Regarding the fracture angle θ, please note that, in Test Case 6, there is a predicted value of θ=90∘ although there is σ2=σ3 both in nominal and in true stresses. This is the result of the given through-thickness tensile strength, which is lower than the transverse tensile strength. The implemented routine is capable of differentiating between the two given strengths R⊥2 t and R⊥3 t and calculates the valid tensile strength R⊥ t(θ) depending on the orientation of the respective action plane. This means that the calculation of the stress exposure fE(θ) on a plane oriented at θ=0∘ is automatically based on R⊥ t(θ)=R⊥2 t while that on a plane at θ=90∘ is dealt with on the basis of R⊥ t(θ)=R⊥3 t. The definition of R⊥ t(θ) for an arbitrary orientation is done by an elliptical interpolation (equation (49)). In Test Case 7, both strengths have the same value and the fracture angle becomes a random value (49)R⊥ t(θ)=R⊥3 t1-a2·cos2θ with a=R⊥2 2-R⊥3 2R⊥2 t

sec.title: Test Case 8
sec.p:
This test case deals with a symmetric ±35 glass/epoxy laminate where the ratio between σx=σz and σy is varied (Figure 21). The influence of residual stresses due to thermal expansion is insignificant for most sections of the curve excluding those in the positive σy-regime (Figure 22). Here, the tensile residual stresses in 2-direction lower the strength of the laminate against the applied tensile load σy while the strength against σz stays unaffected. Figure 19.
Results of Test Case 6: GFRC.
GFRC: glass fibre reinforced concrete. Figure 20.
Results of Test Case 7: CFRC.
CFRC: carbon fibre reinforced concrete. Figure 21.
Results of Test Case 8 indicating the orientation of the fracture plane θfp[∘] in an arbitrary lamina. Figure 22.
Zoom of the results of Test Case 8 indicating the orientation of the fracture plane θfp[∘] in an arbitrary lamina.

The location of the first ply failure is arbitrary since all the laminae are experiencing the same state of stress. While tensile σz excludes that any postfailure degradation process results in a higher bearable load (Figure 21, first and second quadrant), for any other load case, no load redistribution among the laminae is possible either. Where tensile σy leads to tensile σn on the IFF plane (Figure 21(i)), an instable degradation process is expected to begin where the remaining load carrying capacity results from known mutually supporting effects of the successively desintegrating laminae.5 This process is not covered by our continuum-based smeared damage representation. In the remaining load cases (mainly third quadrant), we assume that the inclined IFFs are transmitting compressive σn like before the fracture. Such fractures are generally classified as nontolerable IFFs due to their wedge effect (cp. ‘Considerations on different IFF fracture modes and Successive damage evolution – degradation’ sections). Without being able to predict the quantity of the resulting forces in thickness direction that promote local splitting or delamination, it is evident that these are absorbed to a certain extent by the present compressive σz. Therefore, Figure 23 provides a final fibre-failure curve assuming that no splitting or delamination occurs during the degradation process. During the degradation process, the relevant in-plane shear moduli rapidly reduce to a defined residual value of 25% of the initial value.3,12 Figure 23.
Test Case 8: initial interfibre failure and final fibre failure for those load cases that result in compressive σn (residual stresses neglected).

sec.title: Test Case 9
sec.p:
The results show the deformation of the above lamina while increasingly loaded until σx=σy=σz=-100 MPa (Figure 24). Keeping this level for σx and σz, the compressive σy is further increased until fracture. The nominal fracture stress corresponds to the according load case in Test Case 8 (Figure 21). It is judged unlikely that the small amount of compressive σz absorbes the wedge effect (cp. ‘Test Case 8’ section); hence, no degradation process is started after interfibre failure. Figure 24.
Results of Test Case 9.

sec.title: Test Cases 10 and 11
sec.p:
The two test cases deal with symmetric ±45/90/0 (case 10) and 90/0 (case 11) carbon/epoxy laminates loaded with a varied ratio between σz and τyz (Figure 25). The fracture curves of both cases are identical, because it is the 0°-ply, which fails in both cases while experiencing identical states of stress. It is remarkable that the influence of residual stresses increases from no influence under pure tensile σz-loading to its maximum under pure compressive loading – always keeping in mind that there is no residual stress in the material’s through-thickness direction! The residual stresses in the material’s 2-direction do not influence the stresses on the fracture plane due to tensile σz at θfp=90∘. However, they do influence the stresses on a fracture plane at θfp=41∘ or 139° as it arises from pure compressive σz. In this case, the tensile residual stresses in 2-direction lower the compressive stress σn on the fracture plane and consequently lower its fracture resistance against τnt (cp. ‘Visualisation of the IFF criterion’ section). Figure 25.
Results of Test Cases 10 and 11.

sec.title: Test Case 12
sec.p:
The results show the deformation of the Test Case 11 laminate under compressive σz (Figure 26). The result is based on the scaled σ3(ɛ3)-relation presented in ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section. While the deformation in z-direction enters the nonlinear regime after half the nominal fracture stress applied, ɛx=ɛy stays in the linear regime until fracture. The fracture stresses correspond to Figure 25(i). Figure 26.
Results of Test Case 12.

list-item.p: The objectives of the article are (a) apply Puck’s failure criteria to predict the failure of 12 test problems, proposed in the second World-Wide failure exercise, including polymer material, unidirectional lamina and multidirectional laminate under a variety of 3D stress loadings. The implementation was carried out through a commercial finite element code where material nonlinearity, due to material behaviour under shear and transverse and through-thickness loading and due to post failure damage, was taken into account. The successful methodology developed here will be used to analyse the effects of boundary condition in Part B of the WWFE-II to improve correlation with experimental results for some of the test problems.
Using a RVE with periodic boundary conditions, the analysis provides homogenised laminate behaviour without any undesired boundary effects (cp. ‘RVE approach to derive laminate behaviour’ section).

It is obvious that an applied 3D state of stress may result in a significantly larger number of highly loaded action planes than a 2D problem will ever be able to. Accordingly, Puck’s ηm+p-extension to Mohr’s fracture hypothesis gains superior importance (cp. ‘Influence of nonfracture plane stresses on the IFF’ section). It accounts for the stress exposures on all the action planes by adding a portion to the stress exposure of the fracture plane.

The extended FF criterion accounts for the influence of transverse and through-thickness stresses on the FF. Both, the Poisson’s effects and the local stress concentration around the fibres, are included (cp. ‘Influences of fibre-parallel stress σ1 on the IFF’ section).

In the 3D context, it is emphasised that Puck’s theory is capable of differentiating between given strengths in the transverse and through-thickness direction. Within the WWFE-II, the routine accounts for the two given strengths R⊥2 t and R⊥3 t and calculates the valid tensile strength R⊥ t(θ) depending on the orientation of the respective action plane (cp. ‘Test Cases 6 and 7’ section). It is worth pointing out that, for the Puck criteria to be universally applicable, a delamination criterion should be added to the formulation.

Puck’s theory predicts open IFF fracture curves in cases of equal compressive σ2 and σ3 (cp. ‘Test Case 1 and Test Cases 6 and 7’ sections). Going along with the intuitive imagination that such a combination will not be able to produce any macroscopic IFF, this load combination clearly excesses the capability of a macroscopic model. It is known when the microdamage starts but the speed at which these nuclei merge to a macroscopic failure is expected to be strongly dependent on the experimental setup, and its prediction within a continuum-based model is highly questionable. In the hydrostatic pressure case, the fracture curves are closed by predicted FFs (cp. ‘Test Case 5’ section).

The present implementation takes into account nonlinear constitutive behaviour for shear and transverse and through-thickness compression. However, being subject to combined compressive σ2 and σ3, the material bears much higher loadings than the uniaxial experiments provide stress–strain relations for. As the interval of validity of existing formulations has been exceeded by far, a self-similar scaling approach has been developed (cp. ‘Nonlinear constitutive behaviour’ section).

Besides the WWFE-II, the definition of completely revised 3D degradation algorithms will be a challenging future task. The influence of the fracture plane orientation is not sufficiently covered by the existing methods (cp. ‘Successive damage evolution – degradation’ section).

It is worth pointing out that a comparison between the predictions made in this article and those obtained from other failure criteria will be published in Kaddour and Hinton.38 Also, a comaprsion between the current predictions an experimental data is made in Part B of the WWFE-II.26

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
